companies.name: Accton Technology

profile_json.overview: Accton Technology is a leading ODM (Original Design Manufacturer) of networking equipment, specializing in white-box switches, routers, and wireless access points. The company is a key supplier to hyperscaler data centers and benefits directly from the buildout of AI/cloud infrastructure requiring high-speed networking.
profile_json.thesis: Accton is a prime beneficiary of the AI data center networking upgrade cycle. Demand for 400G/800G white-box switches is accelerating as hyperscalers expand AI clusters. Accton's ODM model offers compelling cost advantages over branded alternatives from Arista and Cisco, driving share gains.

White-box/ODM market share continues to gain vs. branded networking equipment
Hyperscaler customer relationships deepen with next-gen platform wins
Gross margins expand as higher-speed products carry better mix

valuation_scenarios.label: Base Case

valuation_scenarios.label: Bear Case

profile_json.valuation_notes: Accton trades at a significant discount to branded networking peers (Arista at 35x). ODM discount is partly warranted but gap should narrow as AI networking demand validates the white-box model. Key catalyst: 800G product ramp.

focus: Track AI/data center networking switch demand for 400G/800G platforms
Monitor white-box/ODM market share trends vs Arista/Cisco
Watch hyperscaler customer concentration and new customer wins

profile_json.overview: SK Hynix is the world's second-largest memory chipmaker and the undisputed leader in HBM (High Bandwidth Memory) for AI applications. The company supplies HBM3E to Nvidia and other AI chip makers, holds the leading market position in this high-margin segment, and is developing HBM4 for next-generation AI accelerators.
profile_json.thesis: SK Hynix is the highest-conviction memory play on the AI supercycle. The company's dominant HBM position provides a structural revenue and margin uplift that differentiates it from commodity DRAM peers. HBM supply is allocated to Nvidia and hyperscalers through multi-year agreements, providing unprecedented earnings visibility for a memory company.
key_assumptions: HBM revenue grows 50%+ annually through 2027 driven by AI accelerator demand
HBM supply allocation to Nvidia/hyperscalers maintained at premium pricing
Conventional DRAM/NAND pricing recovery supports base business profitability
Advanced packaging capacity expansion for HBM executes on schedule
risk_factors: Samsung HBM qualification at Nvidia would intensify competition
AI capex cycle slowdown would reduce HBM demand growth
DRAM/NAND pricing downturn impacting base business
Advanced packaging capacity bottleneck delays

profile_json.overview: Samsung Electronics is the world's largest memory chipmaker and a major player in semiconductor foundry, displays (OLED, LCD), and consumer electronics (smartphones, TVs). The company is the leading DRAM and NAND supplier globally and is ramping HBM production to compete with SK Hynix for AI-related demand.
profile_json.thesis: Samsung faces a pivotal period. The company needs to execute on HBM3E/HBM4 qualification with Nvidia to participate in the AI memory supercycle, while its foundry business must narrow the yield gap vs TSMC at 3nm/2nm. Memory pricing recovery is supportive, but execution risks in both HBM and foundry create a balanced risk/reward at current levels.
key_assumptions: HBM3E qualification at Nvidia is achieved by mid-2026
Foundry yields at 3nm improve to competitive levels
DRAM/NAND pricing cycle remains favorable through 2026
Memory business carries the company while foundry ramps
risk_factors: HBM qualification delays vs SK Hynix competitive lead
Foundry yield issues at 3nm/2nm persist, losing customers to TSMC
Memory pricing downturn if supply/demand balance shifts
Consumer electronics segment faces margin pressure

focus: Track HBM3E/HBM4 qualification progress vs SK Hynix, particularly Nvidia validation
Monitor foundry yield improvements at 3nm/2nm vs TSMC competitive gap
Watch memory pricing cycle trends and AI-driven DRAM demand signals

profile_json.overview: Screen Holdings (formerly Dainippon Screen) is a Japanese semiconductor equipment company specializing in cleaning, coating, and lithography equipment. The company holds a leading market share in single-wafer cleaning systems, which are critical for advanced node manufacturing. Screen also has a display equipment business.
profile_json.thesis: Screen Holdings benefits from the structural trend toward more cleaning steps at advanced nodes. As EUV and multi-patterning increase, the number of cleaning steps per wafer rises significantly, expanding Screen's addressable market. The company's strong position with foundry and memory customers provides order visibility tied to fab construction cycles.
key_assumptions: Semiconductor cleaning equipment orders grow with fab construction spending
Advanced node adoption increases cleaning steps per wafer by 20-30%
New tool qualifications at foundries and memory makers progress
Display equipment provides counter-cyclical diversification
risk_factors: Fab construction cycle slowdown reduces cleaning equipment orders
Competition from TEL and Lam in cleaning equipment
China export controls could limit equipment sales
Display equipment segment faces structural decline in profitability

profile_json.overview: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) is the world's largest and most technologically advanced semiconductor foundry. The company manufactures chips for leading fabless companies including Apple, Nvidia, AMD, Qualcomm, and Broadcom. TSMC dominates advanced node manufacturing with >90% market share at 5nm and below.
profile_json.thesis: TSMC is the foundational infrastructure provider for the AI revolution. Every major AI accelerator (Nvidia, AMD, Google TPU, custom ASICs) is manufactured by TSMC at leading-edge nodes. The company's N3/N2 technology ramp and unmatched manufacturing scale create a durable competitive moat. AI wafer demand provides a multi-year growth runway with improving margins from favorable mix.
key_assumptions: N3/N2 technology ramp and capacity utilization reach 90%+ by 2027
AI accelerator wafer demand grows 40%+ annually through 2027
Advanced node pricing power is maintained at premium levels
Overseas fab construction (Arizona, Japan, Germany) progresses on schedule
risk_factors: Geopolitical risk to Taiwan-based operations (cross-strait tensions)
Customer concentration (Apple + Nvidia >35% of revenue)
Capital expenditure intensity may pressure free cash flow
Intel foundry competitive entry at 18A/14A nodes

profile_json.overview: Tokyo Electron (TEL) is Japan's largest and the world's third-largest semiconductor equipment maker. Core products span etch systems, CVD/PVD deposition, coater/developers for photolithography, and cleaning systems. TEL is a key beneficiary of leading-edge node transitions and EUV adoption.
profile_json.thesis: TEL is positioned to capture outsized share of the AI-driven capex supercycle. Incremental order momentum is strong, driven by EUV-related deposition layers and advanced packaging demand. China exposure is a risk but manageable at current levels.

EUV multi-patterning drives incremental deposition TAM
China revenue remains at ~25% of sales without further restrictions
Etch market share gains continue vs. Lam Research
risk_factors: Escalation of US/Japan China export controls
Cyclical downturn in memory capex
Yen appreciation impacting competitiveness
Customer concentration risk (TSMC, Samsung)

profile_json.overview: Zhongji Innolight is China's leading optical transceiver company and one of the largest globally, specializing in high-speed optical modules for data center interconnect. The company has emerged as a major supplier of 400G and 800G transceivers to global hyperscalers and is pioneering silicon photonics and LPO (Linear-drive Pluggable Optics) technology.
profile_json.thesis: Zhongji Innolight is at the epicenter of the AI data center optical interconnect buildout. The company's 800G/1.6T product roadmap and silicon photonics capabilities position it as a global leader in next-gen optical modules. Customer diversification across both Chinese and Western hyperscalers provides broad demand exposure, though US entity list risk remains an overhang.
key_assumptions: 800G optical module volumes grow 100%+ in 2025-26 driven by AI data center demand
1.6T product qualification and initial shipments begin in 2026
Silicon photonics and LPO technology leadership is maintained
US entity list risk does not materialize in the near term
risk_factors: US entity list placement would severely restrict access to Western customers

Component supply constraints for high-speed lasers and DSPs
Technology transition risk if silicon photonics commoditizes faster than expected

action_log.summary: New US export control guidance — limited impact on TEL operations

detail_json.what_happened: US Commerce Department issued updated guidance on semiconductor equipment export controls to China. The new rules clarify existing restrictions but do not significantly expand the scope of controlled items relevant to TEL's product portfolio.
detail_json.why_it_matters: China revenue risk remains a key assumption in the thesis. While this update is not material, it signals continued regulatory attention. TEL's China revenue (~25% of sales) remains exposed to potential future escalation.
detail_json.recommended_action: No change to investment view. Continue monitoring for any escalation in Japan-specific export controls.
